title: Aeneid 1 747-754 - Dido falls in love - Set 1

content.question: Ingeminant plausu Tyrii, Troesque sequuntur. Nec non et vario noctem sermone trahebat infelix Dido longumque bibebat amorem, multa super Priamo rogitans, super Hectore multa; 5nunc quibus Aurorae venisset filius armis, nunc quales Diomedis equi, nunc quantus Achilles. "Immo age et a prima dic, hospes, origine nobis insidias" inquit "Danaum casusque tuorum." Aeneid 1. 747-754 Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question. 1. (A) Identify one and only one literary device found in line 1 (Ingeminant . . . sequuntur) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it. 2. Identify two Latin nouns in this passage that are ablative of means. 3. In lines 1-4 (Ingeminant . . . multa), which two Latin words indicate that Dido was prolonging the time spent with Aeneas? 4. (A) What are the case and number of multa (line 4) ? (B) Translate it in context. 5. In lines 3-6 (infelix . . . Achilles), (A) identify the subjunctive verb and (B) explain why it is in the subjunctive. 6. Which two Latin words in this passage can be translated as “the misfortunes of your people”? 7. Briefly explain how, according to Book 1, Dido falls in love with Aeneas. Answer in 1 to 2 complete sentences.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
